original: Evermark, Nils Gottfrid, civilingenjör, rektor, Norrköping, f. 12/7/97 i Svensköp, Malmöh. 1. G. 27 m. Anna Westin. Barn: Gunnar f. 28, Gudrun 32, Sonja 34, Bertil 44. — Stud:ex. 17, KTH 23. Res. t. Tyskl. 21, Tyskl., Schweiz o. Frankr. 28. Affärsing. i Ing:firma Ture N. Steen A-B 25-30, lär. o. fackavd:förest. v. STI 30-39, lär. v. Alnarps lantbr:-, mejeri- o. trädg:inst. 39-45, rektor v. Lunds stads yrkessk. 40-44, lär. v. tekn. gymn. i Malmö 40-43, lär. v. Hässleholms tekn. sk. 43-44, rektor v. Norrköp. stads yrkessk. sed. 44. Led. av komm. f. de part. arb :föras yrkesut-bildn., led. av Sv. tekn:fören.. Norrköp. hantv :fören., Sv. yrkessk :fören. m. fl. Skr.: Kompendium i elektro-maskinlära o. elektr. anläggn :teknik (35), Lärobok i anal. geometri, differential- o. integralkalkyl (37), förf. kurser f. Brevskolan 36-38 o. Hermods korresp :inst. 46-47.
translated: Evermark, Nils Gottfrid was a civil engineer and rector from Norrköping, born on July 12, 1897 in Svensköp, Malmö. He married Anna Westin in 1927 and they had four children: Gunnar (born 1928), Gudrun (born 1932), Sonja (born 1934), and Bertil (born 1944). He graduated from secondary school in 1917 and from the Royal Institute of Technology in 1923. He traveled to Germany in 1921 and to Germany, Switzerland and France in 1928. He worked in business management at engineering firm Ture N. Steen A-B from 1925 to 1930, was a teacher and head of department at STI from 1930 to 1939, a teacher at the Alnarp Institute of Agriculture, Dairy and Horticulture from 1939 to 1945, rector of Lund City Vocational School from 1940 to 1944, teacher at the Technical Gymnasium in Malmö from 1940 to 1943, teacher at Hässleholm Technical School from 1943 to 1944, and finally rector of Norrköping City Vocational School from 1944 onwards. He was a member of the commission for private vocational education and a member of the Swedish Society of Engineering. He was also a member of Norrköping Craftsmen's Association, the Swedish Vocational School Association and others. He wrote several books including "Compendium in Electro-Mechanics and Electrical Installation Technology" (1935) and "Textbook in Analytic Geometry, Differential and Integral Calculus" (1937), and developed courses for correspondence schools.
